author: owleksiyowpckcr
content: I think it's intentionally limited. to: 1) reduce EVM complexity/room for errors/attack vectors; 2) make adding new opcodes harder => there's more thought put into new things

author: ajsutton
content: nah, opcodes are currently just a single byte because its nice and compact and there hasn't been any need for more than 256 yet.  If needed it would be possible to introduce 2 byte opcodes in the future (ie if the first byte is 0xFF then read the second byte to determine the opcode).

author: mheuer

author: greg_vardy
content: Just submitted my first geth PR, its #22974 and fixes #22580. There’s a global in there that I know shouldn’t be , so I need feedback on the appropriate place to put it, my first though was in handler in the Ethereum struct,  but I’m not sure that’s appropriate.

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Hi everyone! I am Albus, a mathematician and data scientist who wants to contribute to Ethereum. My main interests are anything related to state management in Ethereum, such as statelessness, state expiry, new ways to store state such as KZG Verkle trees, increasing address size from 20 to 32 bytes etc.

author: xlrkoa
content: Hey guys! I'm Daniel, a nuclear engineer from Toronto, Ontario. I mainly work with C and python, for high performance simulations. I've been wanting to have some experience working with Go, so I've been following ethereum development for a while on the geth implementation. I'd like to contribute to sharding and statelessness developments.
